heading: A GHOST OF A CHANCE. (FROM THE WEEKLY DISPATCH.) IN ST ARTHURS REET, ST LUKE'S, IS—COURT, AN ANCIENT PLACE WITH AN IRON TABLET AT THE NARROW ARCHED ENTRANCE STATING ITS EXTREME AGE. THE PLACE IS NOW UNINHABITED, THE TENANTS HAVING BEEN RECENTLY TURNED OUT. WE FOUND TWO WORKMEN BUSY IN THE COURT, AND ONE OF THEM HAD JUST PRISED A HEAVY WOODEN TRAP WHICH HAD BEEN SECURELY CEMENTED IN THE PAVEMENT, AND THE OPENING DISCLOSED A GULF AT LEAST TWELVE FEET DEEP AND EXTENDING UNDER ALL THE HOUSES ON EITHER SIDE. STRANGELY ENOUGH, MY GUIDE, A CITY MISSIONARY, WHO HAD BEEN FAMILIAR WITH THE PLACE FOR FIFTEEN YEARS PAST, KNEW NOTHING OF THE EXISTENCE OF THIS VAST VAULT, NOR TO HIS KNOWLEDGE WERE ANY OF THE INHABITANTS AWARE OF IT.— STANDARD, 9TH SEPTEMBER, 1875.
